title: Domaþund
body:
History

Origin - The Age of Creation

See Saga Epic


The Age of Races

The Doma soon found a lifelong enemy in the Ëman race. The Doma's innate greed pushed them further afield in their territorial pursuits, which soon reach Ëman lands.

See: Erman-Dommahound Conflict.

Ћumans reached the Western reaches of Domasmï. Many of the humans became subservient Domaþund, and soon worshipped the Doma as if they were god. These Ћumans, named the INSERT NAME, built many settlements and fortresses amongst the mountains of Domasmï.

The Age of Empires

After the defeat in the The War of Ruin, the Domaþund race had been all but eliminated. Only six remained. The remaining group fled.

The Age of Beginnings

An account of an encounter with the remaining Domaþund, in which one was killed, was recorded in a document entitled the "Account of the Slaying of a Dommahound". This brought their numbers down to five.

The Age of Awakening

Having wandered the Lenitä Sands for many Moons, the Doma þundfelt the presence of their creator arise from the depths and followed it to the Indit Region. During their search they were reunited with the Aza’Dür, which had also felt its creator's presence. Together they travelled first to Mutasaih, to where the lingering scent of Urünaen remained, but they found only its citizens. They killed all within the Citadel before moving on towards Gorjovak, where they joined in the Battle of Darkness. Seeing that the Dark Conjurer, their creator's puppet, had been defeated, they fled once again. However this time they had already been reunited with Urunaün, who promises them a return to their former glory after hearing their pleas.

Appearance

The Dommahound are an immortal species and do not age, however their health is determined on their power. During The Age of Races, when the Dommahound were at their strongest, they took on a much more human form. Their skin was dark grey like sooted ash, and the colour of their eyes varied from yellow the green. Their teeth were sharpened, for they are completely carnivorous, and have long nail-like claws. During The Age of Beginning and The Age of Awakening, their power had depleted and their bodies began to rot. Wherever they travelled they left the trace of their decay in the form of black tar-like oil. Nonetheless, they remained immortal and stornger than any mortal being.

Governance

Dommaking

Although not technically a monarchy, the leader of the Dommahound is called the Dommaking. The title is earned through primative dominance, and the Dommaking is required to defend his position from the innevitably numerous challenges to the thrown.

The Dommaking sits upon a great throne named Koretchar, which is bult in the shape of a cupped skeletal hand and made of innumerable charred bones. The throne is set upon a dias that, when stood one, has a magnifying affect to make those who stand upon it seem larger than they truly are. The ancient crown is gifted to the Dommaking upon his first victory - a crown made of marbled jade - and is regifted ceremonially upon each successful defending of their title.

Upon achieving the dominant status of Dommaking, the Dommaking will undergo a period of rapid growth, reaching up to twice the height and stature of their previous size.


Notable Domakings

  • Varkut


Notable Domalords

  • Insert


Notable Domaþund

  • Insert

Culture

Individualistic Collectivism

The existence of a Dommahound is one of constant competition, whether it be with other races or amongst themselves. Rules are routinely overthrown, and murder is a common occurance. Dommasmeare had no law against murder, for it was a sign of greater power, but often it was frowned upon for, although the Dommahound were fueled by greed, they knew that in order for the individual to succeed the group must do too. This created a strength sense of collectivisim, where revenge was routinely sought for outsiders that killed one of their kind. Despite this, none would risk their own lives for another Dommahound, and revenge took precendent over protection - even in immediate circumstances.

Ritual Offerings

To their creator the Dommahound often prayed, seeking favours or answers. Through their worship to Urunine they evolved various practicies to appease their creator and have their requests granted:

  • Offer Killing: The Dommahound sacrifice a non-Dommahound.
  • Blood Killing: The Dommahound sacrifice a Dommahound.
  • Blood Offering: A prisoner, or Dommahound, is drained of blood just before the point of death. This blood is then used to fertilise the land or rivers of Dommasmeare.
  • Red Tide: The Dommahound invade a town, killing all they encounter but taking none of the town's riches. Any Dommahound caught taking valuables from a Red Tide becomes a Blood Killing.
  • Long Night: The Dommahound take a non-Dommahound live offering and tie them up upon an X-shaped cross. Gradually throughout the night they scewer red-hot nails through the offering's body that seal the wounds as soon as they were made. The processes starts from the hands and feet, working their way along the arms and legs towards the body, and then finally through the torso itself. When the torso is reached, nails are first skewered in non-fatal positions. The last nail goes through the heart, and the offering of the Long Night is complete.
  • Rolling Stone: A life offering's arms and legs are removed, and their wounds sealed. Once sufficiently healed, the limbless offering is tossed down the mountain side, eventually arriving to a lake - should the offering survive the fall, drowning awaits.

Genealogy

Reproduction

The Dommahound do not reproduce in the same way as their Human and Astanan counterparts, and instead share the same method of reproduction as their Erman enemies. A Dommahound is genetically neither male nor female, but a combination of both, and their perceived gender of masculine or feminine traits merely an expression of their genetic makeup. However, only those whose genes expressed the individual to be a female had the ability to reproduce, yet no form of procreation was required. They carry their child for a complete Moon.

Their offspring look very similar their Bearer (the name given to the carrier of the child - the concepts of Mother and Father were unknown), but not identical.

Although there are "male" and "female" Dommahound, they are monomorphic, and are all referred to in the masculine sense by the other races (the Dommahound do not use masculine/feminine pronouns or gendered language).

Seeing that the Dark Conjurer, their creator's puppet, had been defeated, they fled once again. However this time they had already been reunited with Urunaün, who promises them a return to their former glory after hearing their pleas.

Appearance

The Dommahound are an immortal species and do not age, however their health is determined on their power. During The Age of Races, when the Dommahound were at their strongest, they took on a much more human form. Their skin was dark grey like sooted ash, and the colour of their eyes varied from yellow the green. Their teeth were sharpened, for they are completely carnivorous, and have long nail-like claws. During The Age of Beginning and The Age of Awakening, their power had depleted and their bodies began to rot. Wherever they travelled they left the trace of their decay in the form of black tar-like oil. Nonetheless, they remained immortal and stornger than any mortal being.

Governance

Dommaking

Although not technically a monarchy, the leader of the Dommahound is called the Dommaking. The title is earned through primative dominance, and the Dommaking is required to defend his position from the innevitably numerous challenges to the thrown.

The Dommaking sits upon a great throne named Koretchar, which is bult in the shape of a cupped skeletal hand and made of innumerable charred bones. The throne is set upon a dias that, when stood one, has a magnifying affect to make those who stand upon it seem larger than they truly are. The ancient crown is gifted to the Dommaking upon his first victory - a crown made of marbled jade - and is regifted ceremonially upon each successful defending of their title.

Upon achieving the dominant status of Dommaking, the Dommaking will undergo a period of rapid growth, reaching up to twice the height and stature of their previous size.


Notable Domakings

  • Varkut


Notable Domalords

  • Insert


Notable Domaþund

  • Insert

Culture

Individualistic Collectivism

The existence of a Dommahound is one of constant competition, whether it be with other races or amongst themselves. Rules are routinely overthrown, and murder is a common occurance. Dommasmeare had no law against murder, for it was a sign of greater power, but often it was frowned upon for, although the Dommahound were fueled by greed, they knew that in order for the individual to succeed the group must do too. This created a strength sense of collectivisim, where revenge was routinely sought for outsiders that killed one of their kind. Despite this, none would risk their own lives for another Dommahound, and revenge took precendent over protection - even in immediate circumstances.

Ritual Offerings

To their creator the Dommahound often prayed, seeking favours or answers. Through their worship to Urunine they evolved various practicies to appease their creator and have their requests granted:

  • Offer Killing: The Dommahound sacrifice a non-Dommahound.
  • Blood Killing: The Dommahound sacrifice a Dommahound.
  • Blood Offering: A prisoner, or Dommahound, is drained of blood just before the point of death. This blood is then used to fertilise the land or rivers of Dommasmeare.
  • Red Tide: The Dommahound invade a town, killing all they encounter but taking none of the town's riches. Any Dommahound caught taking valuables from a Red Tide becomes a Blood Killing.
  • Long Night: The Dommahound take a non-Dommahound live offering and tie them up upon an X-shaped cross. Gradually throughout the night they scewer red-hot nails through the offering's body that seal the wounds as soon as they were made. The processes starts from the hands and feet, working their way along the arms and legs towards the body, and then finally through the torso itself. When the torso is reached, nails are first skewered in non-fatal positions. The last nail goes through the heart, and the offering of the Long Night is complete.
  • Rolling Stone: A life offering's arms and legs are removed, and their wounds sealed. Once sufficiently healed, the limbless offering is tossed down the mountain side, eventually arriving to a lake - should the offering survive the fall, drowning awaits.

Genealogy

Reproduction

The Dommahound do not reproduce in the same way as their Human and Astanan counterparts, and instead share the same method of reproduction as their Erman enemies. A Dommahound is genetically neither male nor female, but a combination of both, and their perceived gender of masculine or feminine traits merely an expression of their genetic makeup. However, only those whose genes expressed the individual to be a female had the ability to reproduce, yet no form of procreation was required. They carry their child for a complete Moon.

Their offspring look very similar their Bearer (the name given to the carrier of the child - the concepts of Mother and Father were unknown), but not identical.

Although there are "male" and "female" Dommahound, they are monomorphic, and are all referred to in the masculine sense by the other races (the Dommahound do not use masculine/feminine pronouns or gendered language).

The throne is set upon a dias that, when stood upon, has a magnifying affect to make those who stand upon it seem larger than they truly are. The ancient crown is gifted to the Domaking upon his first victory - a crown made of marbled jade - and is regifted ceremonially upon each successful defending of their title.

Upon achieving the dominant status of Domaking, the Domaking will undergo a period of rapid growth, reaching up to twice the height and stature of their previous size.


Notable Domakings

  • Varkut


Notable Domalords

  • Insert


Notable Domaþund

  • Insert

Culture

Individualistic Collectivism

The existence of a Domaþund is one of constant competition, whether it be with other races or amongst themselves. Rules are routinely overthrown, and murder is a common occurance. Domasmï had no law against murder, for it was a sign of greater power, but often it was frowned upon for, although the Dommahound were fueled by greed they knew that in order for the individual to succeed the group must do too. This created a strength sense of collectivisim, where revenge was routinely sought for outsiders that killed one of their kind. Despite this, none would risk their own lives for another Domaþund, and revenge took precendent over protection - even in immediate circumstances.

Ritual Offerings

To their creator the Domaþund often prayed, seeking favours or answers. Through their worship to Urünaen they evolved various practicies to appease their creator and have their requests granted:

  • Offer Killing: The Domaþund sacrifice a non-Domaþund.
  • Blood Killing: The Domaþund sacrifice a Domaþund.
  • Blood Offering: A prisoner, or Domaþund, is drained of blood just before the point of death. This blood is then used to fertilise the land or rivers of Domasmï.
  • Red Tide: The Domaþund invade a town, killing all they encounter but taking none of the town's riches. Any Domaþund caught taking valuables from a Red Tide becomes a Blood Killing.
  • Long Night: The Domaþund take a non-Domaþund live offering and tie them up upon an X-shaped cross. Gradually throughout the night they scewer red-hot nails through the offering's body that seal the wounds as soon as they were made. The processes starts from the hands and feet, working their way along the arms and legs towards the body, and then finally through the torso itself. When the torso is reached, nails are first skewered in non-fatal positions. The last nail goes through the heart, and the offering of the Long Night is complete.
  • Rolling Stone: A life offering's arms and legs are removed, and their wounds sealed. Once sufficiently healed, the limbless offering is tossed down the mountain side, eventually arriving to a lake - should the offering survive the fall, drowning awaits.

Genealogy

Reproduction

The Domaþund are asexual. When the Domaþund reproduce, both sexual partners bare offspring. They carry their child for a complete Moon.

title: Domaþund
body:
History

Origin - The Age of Creation

See Saga Epic


The Age of Races

The Doma soon found a lifelong enemy in the Ëman race. The Doma's innate greed pushed them further afield in their territorial pursuits, which soon reach Ëman lands.

See Ëman-Domaþund Conflict.

Ћumans reached the Western reaches of Domasmï. Many of the humans became subservient Domaþund, and soon worshipped the Doma as if they were god. These Ћumans, named the INSERT NAME, built many settlements and fortresses amongst the mountains of Domasmï.

The Age of Empires

After the defeat in the The War of Ruin, the Domaþund race had been all but eliminated. Only six remained. The remaining group fled.

The Age of Beginnings

An account of an encounter with the remaining Domaþund, in which one was killed, was recorded in a document entitled the "Account of the Slaying of a Dommahound". This brought their numbers down to five.

The Age of Awakening

Having wandered the Lenitä Sands for many Moons, the Doma þundfelt the presence of their creator arise from the depths and followed it to the Indit Region. During their search they were reunited with the Aza’Dür, which had also felt its creator's presence. Together they travelled first to Mutasaih, to where the lingering scent of Urünaen remained, but they found only its citizens. They killed all within the Citadel before moving on towards Gorjovak, where they joined in the Battle of Darkness. Seeing that the Dark Conjurer, their creator's puppet, had been defeated, they fled once again. However this time they had already been reunited with Urunaün, who promises them a return to their former glory after hearing their pleas.

Appearance

The Domaþund are an immortal species that do not age, but the health of their body is directly correlated with their dominance. During The Age of Races, when the Domaþund were at their strongest, they took on a much more human form. Their skin was dark grey like sooted ash, and the colour of their eyes varied, from yellow to green to orange. Their teeth were sharp, being completely carnivorous, and have long nail-like claws.

During The Age of Beginning and The Age of Awakening, their power had depleted and their bodies began to fail, taking on a rotten appearance. Wherever they travelled they left the trace of their decay in the form of black tar-like oil. Nonetheless they remained immortal, and stronger than any mortal being.

Genealogy

Reproduction

The Dommahound do not reproduce in the same way as their Human and Astanan counterparts, and instead share the same method of reproduction as their Erman enemies. A Dommahound is genetically neither male nor female, but a combination of both, and their perceived gender of masculine or feminine traits merely an expression of their genetic makeup. However, only those whose genes expressed the individual to be a female had the ability to reproduce, yet no form of procreation was required. They carry their child for a complete Moon.

Their offspring look very similar their Bearer (the name given to the carrier of the child - the concepts of Mother and Father were unknown), but not identical.

Although there are "male" and "female" Dommahound, they are monomorphic, and are all referred to in the masculine sense by the other races (the Dommahound do not use masculine/feminine pronouns or gendered language).

Genealogy

Reproduction

The Dommahound do not reproduce in the same way as their Human and Astanan counterparts, and instead share the same method of reproduction as their Erman enemies. A Dommahound is genetically neither male nor female, but a combination of both, and their perceived gender of masculine or feminine traits merely an expression of their genetic makeup. However, only those whose genes expressed the individual to be a female had the ability to reproduce, yet no form of procreation was required. They carry their child for a complete Moon.

Their offspring look very similar their Bearer (the name given to the carrier of the child - the concepts of Mother and Father were unknown), but not identical.

Although there are "male" and "female" Dommahound, they are monomorphic, and are all referred to in the masculine sense by the other races (the Dommahound do not use masculine/feminine pronouns or gendered language).

The Doma soon found a lifelong enemy in the Ëman race. The Doma's innate greed pushed them further afield in their territorial pursuits, which soon reach Ëman lands.

See Ëman-Domaþund Conflict.

Ћumans reached the Western reaches of Domasmï. Many of the humans became subservient Domaþund, and soon worshipped the Doma as if they were god. These Ћumans, named the INSERT NAME, built many settlements and fortresses amongst the mountains of Domasmï.

The Age of Empires

After the defeat in the The War of Ruin, the Domaþund race had been all but eliminated. Only six remained. The remaining group fled.

The Age of Beginnings

An account of an encounter with the remaining Domaþund, in which one was killed, was recorded in a document entitled the "Account of the Slaying of a Dommahound". This brought their numbers down to five.

The Age of Awakening

Having wandered the Lenitä Sands for many Moons, the Doma þundfelt the presence of their creator arise from the depths and followed it to the Indit Region. During their search they were reunited with the Aza’Dür, which had also felt its creator's presence. Together they travelled first to Mutasaih, to where the lingering scent of Urünaen remained, but they found only its citizens. They killed all within the Citadel before moving on towards Gorjovak, where they joined in the Battle of Darkness. Seeing that the Dark Conjurer, their creator's puppet, had been defeated, they fled once again. However this time they had already been reunited with Urunaün, who promises them a return to their former glory after hearing their pleas.

Appearance

The Domaþund are an immortal species that do not age, but the health of their body is directly correlated with their dominance. During The Age of Races, when the Domaþund were at their strongest, they took on a much more human form. Their skin was dark grey like sooted ash, and the colour of their eyes varied, from yellow to green to orange. Their teeth were sharp, being completely carnivorous, and have long nail-like claws.

During The Age of Beginning and The Age of Awakening, their power had depleted and their bodies began to fail, taking on a rotten appearance. Wherever they travelled they left the trace of their decay in the form of black tar-like oil. Nonetheless they remained immortal, and stronger than any mortal being.

Governance

Dommaking

The Domaþund are ruled by a Domaking. The title is earned through primative dominance, and the Domaking is required to defend his position from the innevitably numerous challenges to the throne.

The Domaking sits upon a great throne named Körechä, which is bult in the shape of a cupped skeletal hand and made of innumerable charred bones. The throne is set upon a dias that, when stood upon, has a magnifying affect to make those who stand upon it seem larger than they truly are. The ancient crown is gifted to the Domaking upon his first victory - a crown made of marbled jade - and is regifted ceremonially upon each successful defending of their title.

Upon achieving the dominant status of Domaking, the Domaking will undergo a period of rapid growth, reaching up to twice the height and stature of their previous size.


Notable Domakings

  • Varkut


Notable Domalords

  • Insert


Notable Domaþund

  • Insert

Culture

Individualistic Collectivism

The existence of a Domaþund is one of constant competition, whether it be with other races or amongst themselves. Rules are routinely overthrown, and murder is a common occurance. Domasmï had no law against murder, for it was a sign of greater power, but often it was frowned upon for, although the Dommahound were fueled by greed they knew that in order for the individual to succeed the group must do too. This created a strength sense of collectivisim, where revenge was routinely sought for outsiders that killed one of their kind. Despite this, none would risk their own lives for another Domaþund, and revenge took precendent over protection - even in immediate circumstances.

Ritual Offerings

To their creator the Domaþund often prayed, seeking favours or answers. Through their worship to Urünaen they evolved various practicies to appease their creator and have their requests granted:

  • Offer Killing: The Domaþund sacrifice a non-Domaþund.
  • Blood Killing: The Domaþund sacrifice a Domaþund.
  • Blood Offering: A prisoner, or Domaþund, is drained of blood just before the point of death. This blood is then used to fertilise the land or rivers of Domasmï.
  • Red Tide: The Domaþund invade a town, killing all they encounter but taking none of the town's riches. Any Domaþund caught taking valuables from a Red Tide becomes a Blood Killing.
  • Long Night: The Domaþund take a non-Domaþund live offering and tie them up upon an X-shaped cross. Gradually throughout the night they scewer red-hot nails through the offering's body that seal the wounds as soon as they were made. The processes starts from the hands and feet, working their way along the arms and legs towards the body, and then finally through the torso itself. When the torso is reached, nails are first skewered in non-fatal positions. The last nail goes through the heart, and the offering of the Long Night is complete.
  • Rolling Stone: A life offering's arms and legs are removed, and their wounds sealed. Once sufficiently healed, the limbless offering is tossed down the mountain side, eventually arriving to a lake - should the offering survive the fall, drowning awaits.

Genealogy

Reproduction

The Domaþund are asexual. When the Domaþund reproduce, both sexual partners bare offspring. They carry their child for a complete Moon.

Although not technically a monarchy, the leader of the Dommahound is called the Dommaking. The title is earned through primative dominance, and the Dommaking is required to defend his position from the innevitably numerous challenges to the thrown.

The Dommaking sits upon a great throne named Koretchar, which is bult in the shape of a cupped skeletal hand and made of innumerable charred bones. The throne is set upon a dias that, when stood one, has a magnifying affect to make those who stand upon it seem larger than they truly are. The ancient crown is gifted to the Dommaking upon his first victory - a crown made of marbled jade - and is regifted ceremonially upon each successful defending of their title.

Upon achieving the dominant status of Dommaking, the Dommaking will undergo a period of rapid growth, reaching up to twice the height and stature of their previous size.


Notable Domakings

  • Varkut


Notable Domalords

  • Insert


Notable Domaþund

  • Insert

Culture

Individualistic Collectivism

The existence of a Dommahound is one of constant competition, whether it be with other races or amongst themselves. Rules are routinely overthrown, and murder is a common occurance. Dommasmeare had no law against murder, for it was a sign of greater power, but often it was frowned upon for, although the Dommahound were fueled by greed, they knew that in order for the individual to succeed the group must do too. This created a strength sense of collectivisim, where revenge was routinely sought for outsiders that killed one of their kind. Despite this, none would risk their own lives for another Dommahound, and revenge took precendent over protection - even in immediate circumstances.

Ritual Offerings

To their creator the Dommahound often prayed, seeking favours or answers. Through their worship to Urunine they evolved various practicies to appease their creator and have their requests granted:

  • Offer Killing: The Dommahound sacrifice a non-Dommahound.
  • Blood Killing: The Dommahound sacrifice a Dommahound.
  • Blood Offering: A prisoner, or Dommahound, is drained of blood just before the point of death. This blood is then used to fertilise the land or rivers of Dommasmeare.
  • Red Tide: The Dommahound invade a town, killing all they encounter but taking none of the town's riches. Any Dommahound caught taking valuables from a Red Tide becomes a Blood Killing.
  • Long Night: The Dommahound take a non-Dommahound live offering and tie them up upon an X-shaped cross. Gradually throughout the night they scewer red-hot nails through the offering's body that seal the wounds as soon as they were made. The processes starts from the hands and feet, working their way along the arms and legs towards the body, and then finally through the torso itself. When the torso is reached, nails are first skewered in non-fatal positions. The last nail goes through the heart, and the offering of the Long Night is complete.
  • Rolling Stone: A life offering's arms and legs are removed, and their wounds sealed. Once sufficiently healed, the limbless offering is tossed down the mountain side, eventually arriving to a lake - should the offering survive the fall, drowning awaits.

Genealogy

Reproduction

The Dommahound do not reproduce in the same way as their Human and Astanan counterparts, and instead share the same method of reproduction as their Erman enemies. A Dommahound is genetically neither male nor female, but a combination of both, and their perceived gender of masculine or feminine traits merely an expression of their genetic makeup. However, only those whose genes expressed the individual to be a female had the ability to reproduce, yet no form of procreation was required. They carry their child for a complete Moon.

Their offspring look very similar their Bearer (the name given to the carrier of the child - the concepts of Mother and Father were unknown), but not identical.

Although there are "male" and "female" Dommahound, they are monomorphic, and are all referred to in the masculine sense by the other races (the Dommahound do not use masculine/feminine pronouns or gendered language).

title: Domaþund
body:
History

Origin - The Age of Creation

See Saga Epic


The Age of Races

The Doma soon found a lifelong enemy in the Ëman race. The Doma's innate greed pushed them further afield in their territorial pursuits, which soon reach Ëman lands.

See Ëman-Domaþund Conflict.

Ћumans reached the Western reaches of Domasmï. Many of the humans became subservient Domaþund, and soon worshipped the Doma as if they were god. These Ћumans, named the INSERT NAME, built many settlements and fortresses amongst the mountains of Domasmï.

The Age of Empires

After the defeat in the The War of Ruin, the Domaþund race had been all but eliminated. Only six remained. The remaining group fled.

The Age of Beginnings

An account of an encounter with the remaining Domaþund, in which one was killed, was recorded in a document entitled the "Account of the Slaying of a Dommahound". This brought their numbers down to five.

The Age of Awakening

Having wandered the Lenitä Sands for many Moons, the Doma þundfelt the presence of their creator arise from the depths and followed it to the Indit Region. During their search they were reunited with the Aza’Dür, which had also felt its creator's presence. Together they travelled first to Mutasaih, to where the lingering scent of Urünaen remained, but they found only its citizens. They killed all within the Citadel before moving on towards Gorjovak, where they joined in the Battle of Darkness. Seeing that the Dark Conjurer, their creator's puppet, had been defeated, they fled once again. However this time they had already been reunited with Urunaün, who promises them a return to their former glory after hearing their pleas.

Appearance

The Domaþund are an immortal species that do not age, but the health of their body is directly correlated with their dominance. During The Age of Races, when the Domaþund were at their strongest, they took on a much more human form. Their skin was dark grey like sooted ash, and the colour of their eyes varied, from yellow to green to orange. Their teeth were sharp, being completely carnivorous, and have long nail-like claws.

During The Age of Beginning and The Age of Awakening, their power had depleted and their bodies began to fail, taking on a rotten appearance. Wherever they travelled they left the trace of their decay in the form of black tar-like oil. Nonetheless they remained immortal, and stronger than any mortal being.

The Domaþund are ruled by a Domaking. The title is earned through primative dominance, and the Domaking is required to defend his position from the innevitably numerous challenges to the throne.

The throne is set upon a dias that, when stood upon, has a magnifying affect to make those who stand upon it seem larger than they truly are. The ancient crown is gifted to the Domaking upon his first victory - a crown made of marbled jade - and is regifted ceremonially upon each successful defending of their title.

Upon achieving the dominant status of Domaking, the Domaking will undergo a period of rapid growth, reaching up to twice the height and stature of their previous size.

preface: The Domaþund are a race of humanoids created by Urünaen during The Age of Creation.

title: Domaþund
body:
History

Origin - The Age of Creation

See Saga Epic


The Age of Races

The Doma soon found a lifelong enemy in the Ëman race. The Doma's innate greed pushed them further afield in their territorial pursuits, which soon reach Ëman lands.

See: Erman-Dommahound Conflict.

Ћumans reached the Western reaches of Domasmï. Many of the humans became subservient Domaþund, and soon worshipped the Doma as if they were god. These Ћumans, named the INSERT NAME, built many settlements and fortresses amongst the mountains of Domasmï.

The Age of Empires

After the defeat in the The War of Ruin, the Domaþund race had been all but eliminated. Only six remained. The remaining group fled.

The Age of Beginnings

An account of an encounter with the remaining Domaþund, in which one was killed, was recorded in a document entitled the "Account of the Slaying of a Dommahound". This brought their numbers down to five.

The Age of Awakening

Having wandered the Lenitä Sands for many Moons, the Doma þundfelt the presence of their creator arise from the depths and followed it to the Indit Region. During their search they were reunited with the Aza’Dür, which had also felt its creator's presence. Together they travelled first to Mutasaih, to where the lingering scent of Urünaen remained, but they found only its citizens. They killed all within the Citadel before moving on towards Gorjovak, where they joined in the Battle of Darkness. Seeing that the Dark Conjurer, their creator's puppet, had been defeated, they fled once again. However this time they had already been reunited with Urunaün, who promises them a return to their former glory after hearing their pleas.

Appearance

The Dommahound are an immortal species and do not age, however their health is determined on their power. During The Age of Races, when the Dommahound were at their strongest, they took on a much more human form. Their skin was dark grey like sooted ash, and the colour of their eyes varied from yellow the green. Their teeth were sharpened, for they are completely carnivorous, and have long nail-like claws. During The Age of Beginning and The Age of Awakening, their power had depleted and their bodies began to rot. Wherever they travelled they left the trace of their decay in the form of black tar-like oil. Nonetheless, they remained immortal and stornger than any mortal being.

Governance

Dommaking

Although not technically a monarchy, the leader of the Dommahound is called the Dommaking. The title is earned through primative dominance, and the Dommaking is required to defend his position from the innevitably numerous challenges to the thrown.

The Dommaking sits upon a great throne named Koretchar, which is bult in the shape of a cupped skeletal hand and made of innumerable charred bones. The throne is set upon a dias that, when stood one, has a magnifying affect to make those who stand upon it seem larger than they truly are. The ancient crown is gifted to the Dommaking upon his first victory - a crown made of marbled jade - and is regifted ceremonially upon each successful defending of their title.

Upon achieving the dominant status of Dommaking, the Dommaking will undergo a period of rapid growth, reaching up to twice the height and stature of their previous size.


Notable Domakings

  • Varkut


Notable Domalords

  • Insert


Notable Domaþund

  • Insert

Culture

Individualistic Collectivism

The existence of a Dommahound is one of constant competition, whether it be with other races or amongst themselves. Rules are routinely overthrown, and murder is a common occurance. Dommasmeare had no law against murder, for it was a sign of greater power, but often it was frowned upon for, although the Dommahound were fueled by greed, they knew that in order for the individual to succeed the group must do too. This created a strength sense of collectivisim, where revenge was routinely sought for outsiders that killed one of their kind. Despite this, none would risk their own lives for another Dommahound, and revenge took precendent over protection - even in immediate circumstances.

Ritual Offerings

To their creator the Dommahound often prayed, seeking favours or answers. Through their worship to Urunine they evolved various practicies to appease their creator and have their requests granted:

  • Offer Killing: The Dommahound sacrifice a non-Dommahound.
  • Blood Killing: The Dommahound sacrifice a Dommahound.
  • Blood Offering: A prisoner, or Dommahound, is drained of blood just before the point of death. This blood is then used to fertilise the land or rivers of Dommasmeare.
  • Red Tide: The Dommahound invade a town, killing all they encounter but taking none of the town's riches. Any Dommahound caught taking valuables from a Red Tide becomes a Blood Killing.
  • Long Night: The Dommahound take a non-Dommahound live offering and tie them up upon an X-shaped cross. Gradually throughout the night they scewer red-hot nails through the offering's body that seal the wounds as soon as they were made. The processes starts from the hands and feet, working their way along the arms and legs towards the body, and then finally through the torso itself. When the torso is reached, nails are first skewered in non-fatal positions. The last nail goes through the heart, and the offering of the Long Night is complete.
  • Rolling Stone: A life offering's arms and legs are removed, and their wounds sealed. Once sufficiently healed, the limbless offering is tossed down the mountain side, eventually arriving to a lake - should the offering survive the fall, drowning awaits.

Genealogy

Reproduction

The Dommahound do not reproduce in the same way as their Human and Astanan counterparts, and instead share the same method of reproduction as their Erman enemies. A Dommahound is genetically neither male nor female, but a combination of both, and their perceived gender of masculine or feminine traits merely an expression of their genetic makeup. However, only those whose genes expressed the individual to be a female had the ability to reproduce, yet no form of procreation was required. They carry their child for a complete Moon.

Their offspring look very similar their Bearer (the name given to the carrier of the child - the concepts of Mother and Father were unknown), but not identical.

Although there are "male" and "female" Dommahound, they are monomorphic, and are all referred to in the masculine sense by the other races (the Dommahound do not use masculine/feminine pronouns or gendered language).

History

Origin - The Age of Creation

See Saga Epic


The Age of Races

The Doma soon found a lifelong enemy in the Ëman race. The Doma's innate greed pushed them further afield in their territorial pursuits, which soon reach Ëman lands.

See Ëman-Domaþund Conflict.

Ћumans reached the Western reaches of Domasmï. Many of the humans became subservient Domaþund, and soon worshipped the Doma as if they were god. These Ћumans, named the INSERT NAME, built many settlements and fortresses amongst the mountains of Domasmï.

The Age of Empires

After the defeat in the The War of Ruin, the Domaþund race had been all but eliminated. Only six remained. The remaining group fled.

The Age of Beginnings

An account of an encounter with the remaining Domaþund, in which one was killed, was recorded in a document entitled the "Account of the Slaying of a Dommahound". This brought their numbers down to five.

The Age of Awakening

Having wandered the Lenitä Sands for many Moons, the Doma þundfelt the presence of their creator arise from the depths and followed it to the Indit Region. During their search they were reunited with the Aza’Dür, which had also felt its creator's presence. Together they travelled first to Mutasaih, to where the lingering scent of Urünaen remained, but they found only its citizens. They killed all within the Citadel before moving on towards Gorjovak, where they joined in the Battle of Darkness. Seeing that the Dark Conjurer, their creator's puppet, had been defeated, they fled once again. However this time they had already been reunited with Urunaün, who promises them a return to their former glory after hearing their pleas.

Appearance

The Domaþund are an immortal species that do not age, but the health of their body is directly correlated with their dominance. During The Age of Races, when the Domaþund were at their strongest, they took on a much more human form. Their skin was dark grey like sooted ash, and the colour of their eyes varied, from yellow to green to orange. Their teeth were sharp, being completely carnivorous, and have long nail-like claws.

During The Age of Beginning and The Age of Awakening, their power had depleted and their bodies began to fail, taking on a rotten appearance. Wherever they travelled they left the trace of their decay in the form of black tar-like oil. Nonetheless they remained immortal, and stronger than any mortal being.

Governance

Dommaking

The Domaþund are ruled by a Domaking. The title is earned through primative dominance, and the Domaking is required to defend his position from the innevitably numerous challenges to the throne.

The Domaking sits upon a great throne named Körechä, which is bult in the shape of a cupped skeletal hand and made of innumerable charred bones. The throne is set upon a dias that, when stood upon, has a magnifying affect to make those who stand upon it seem larger than they truly are. The ancient crown is gifted to the Domaking upon his first victory - a crown made of marbled jade - and is regifted ceremonially upon each successful defending of their title.

Upon achieving the dominant status of Domaking, the Domaking will undergo a period of rapid growth, reaching up to twice the height and stature of their previous size.


Notable Domakings

  • Maltiemun
  • Väkut


Notable Domalords

  • Koezut
  • Toepoitun

Notable Domapriests

  • Balzamut
  • Lofamun
  • Kësakut


Notable Domaþund

  • Insert

Culture

Individualistic Collectivism

The existence of a Domaþund is one of constant competition, whether it be with other races or amongst themselves. Rules are routinely overthrown, and murder is a common occurance. Domasmï had no law against murder, for it was a sign of greater power, but often it was frowned upon for, although the Dommahound were fueled by greed they knew that in order for the individual to succeed the group must do too. This created a strength sense of collectivisim, where revenge was routinely sought for outsiders that killed one of their kind. Despite this, none would risk their own lives for another Domaþund, and revenge took precendent over protection - even in immediate circumstances.

Ritual Offerings

To their creator the Domaþund often prayed, seeking favours or answers. Through their worship to Urünaen they evolved various practicies to appease their creator and have their requests granted:

  • Offer Killing: The Domaþund sacrifice a non-Domaþund.
  • Blood Killing: The Domaþund sacrifice a Domaþund.
  • Blood Offering: A prisoner, or Domaþund, is drained of blood just before the point of death. This blood is then used to fertilise the land or rivers of Domasmï.
  • Red Tide: The Domaþund invade a town, killing all they encounter but taking none of the town's riches. Any Domaþund caught taking valuables from a Red Tide becomes a Blood Killing.
  • Long Night: The Domaþund take a non-Domaþund live offering and tie them up upon an X-shaped cross. Gradually throughout the night they scewer red-hot nails through the offering's body that seal the wounds as soon as they were made. The processes starts from the hands and feet, working their way along the arms and legs towards the body, and then finally through the torso itself. When the torso is reached, nails are first skewered in non-fatal positions. The last nail goes through the heart, and the offering of the Long Night is complete.
  • Rolling Stone: A life offering's arms and legs are removed, and their wounds sealed. Once sufficiently healed, the limbless offering is tossed down the mountain side, eventually arriving to a lake - should the offering survive the fall, drowning awaits.

Genealogy

Reproduction

The Domaþund are asexual. When the Domaþund reproduce, both sexual partners bare offspring. They carry their child for a complete Moon.
preface: The Domaþund are a race of humanoids created by Urünaen during The Age of Creation.
